column1: UNICEF, WHO, World Bank Group Joint Malnutrition Estimates, May 2022 Edition.                  Wasting prevalence and numbers affected (millions) 2020.*

Wasting refers to a child who is too thin for his or her height. Wasting, or acute malnutrition, is the result of recent rapid weight loss or the failure to gain weight. A child who is moderately or severely wasted has an increased risk of death, but treatment is possible.
Wasting (moderate and severe): percentage/number of children aged 0–59 months who are below minus two standard deviations from median weight-for-height of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
Wasting (severe): percentage/number of children aged 0–59 months who are below minus three standard deviations from median weight-for-height of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
Oceania excluding Australia and New Zealand
Oceania excluding Australia and New Zealand
1. Consecutive low population coverage; interpret with caution.
2. Asia excluding Japan; Eastern Asia excluding Japan; Eastern and South-Eastern Asia excluding Japan
3.  For wasting and severe wasting estimates, the Northern America regional average is based only on United States data
4. Eastern Europe and Central Asia excluding Russia
5. The estimates for the year 2020 do not account for the impact of COVID-19.  Household survey data on child height and age were not collected in 2020 due to physical distancing policies.
6. World Bank Income Classification is based on FY 2022 Classification
